title: Alamo Solo Spring
text:
Alamo Solo Spring, (Lone Cottonwood Spring) a spring directly east of the <a href="Dagany%20Gap">Dagany Gap</a> in the <a href="Pyramid%20Hills">Pyramid Hills</a> of <a href="Kern%20County%2C%20California">Kern County, California</a>. Its location appears on a 1914 USGS <a href="Topographic%20map">Topographic map</a> of Lost Hills.
History.
Before the advent of the Spanish, Alamo Solo Spring was the site of a large Indian village covering about 100 <a href="acre">acre</a>s. Alamo Solo Spring was considered one of the most reliable watering places on the route of <a href="El%20Camino%20Viejo">El Camino Viejo</a> in the <a href="San%20Joaquin%20Valley">San Joaquin Valley</a> between <a href="Garza%20Creek">Arroyo de las Garzas</a> and <a href="Salt%20Spring">Aguaje de la Brea</a>. At Alamo Solo Spring the route of El Camino Viejo split, the main route continuing north to Arroyo de las Garzas and beyond and the other turned onto the <a href="El%20Camino%20Viejo%23Eastern%20Route%20of%20El%20Camino%20Viejo">eastern route of the Old Road</a> that passed to the east at <a href="Alamo%20Mocho%20%28Kern%20County%29">Alamo Mocho</a> and on to follow the shore of <a href="Tulare%20Lake">Tulare Lake</a>, proceeding northward across the <a href="Kings%20River%20%28California%29">Kings River</a> to settlements on the <a href="Fresno%20Slough">Fresno Slough</a> and <a href="San%20Joaquin%20River">San Joaquin River</a> before it turned back to rejoin the main route at <a href="Panoche%20Creek">Arroyo de Panoche Grande</a>.
